The really big thing about crew dragon is that almost every expensive part is reuseable:
-the booster with 9 incredibly expensive and complex merlin engines
-the capulse with all the expensive life support equipment.
only the interstage and the 2nd stage with the m-vac is lost. I'd guess they reuse and therefore save at least 90% of the vehicle pricewise.

It's a big step towards reuseability and therefore a big step for affordable spaceflight for everyday people ;)

@32:00 - when talking about water on the moon a lot is made about it being actual water rather than other compounds of hydrogen. It does not really matter that much and indeed water is not necessarily the easiest compound from which to extract hydrogen. This line of thinking probably comes out of the fact that we are used to using electrolysis to easily extract hydrogen from water and the reason for that is simply that water is so plentiful here.
Even if we actually need water it might be easier to make it by extracting hydrogen from a more plentiful compound and combining it with oxygen (which is very easily extracted from regolith) rather than trying to extract it from rocks with a tiny amount of trapped water.
What matters most is the amount of hydrogen per unit volume in the regolith regardless of what it is bound to as the difficulty of extracting ot from one compound or another does not vary that much. It is the actual collection of the 'ore' so to speak that is the most difficult part and if you have to go through 1 ton of ore instead of 100 for a given amount of hydrogen it makes a huge difference.

In my opinion I believe that the rankings for the Hayabusa2 and the Chang’e 5 missions should be switched. The Chang’e 5 is an impressive mission but similar missions have already been successfully flown, many decades ago, with electronics that could be mistaken for steampunk machines. Over 300kg of lunar samples have been returned to earth and 2 more kilograms just seems insignificant. On the other hand only minuscule particles have been collected from asteroids until Hayabusa2 which brought 5g back, relatively speaking that is a lot, especially since this is from an whole new asteroid. Also, bringing back more and more material has its diminishing returns, especially with the sensitivity of modern sensors. Overall I see Chang’e 5 as a big step for China and Hayabusa2 as a big step for humanity as a whole.

I may be a bit biased tho.
